item.title: The Care and Feeding of a Toothbrush
item.description:
There are regular toothbrushes, electric toothbrushes, and even toothbrushes that give little beeps when they think you have had enough. But they all have one thing in common—GERMS. We get two common questions in our dental office about germs on toothbrushes.

After I am sick, what can I do to get the toothbrush clean so I don't get sick again?

The easy answer—Don't worry about boiling it, soaking it in soap and water, or any of the other tricks you hear about or read online. Unless you are on a very tight budget, after you have been sick, throw the thing out and get a new toothbrush! We give our patients a free toothbrush after every cleaning.

And a related question: Is it true that germs on my toothbrush can make me sick? And if so, can I store it some way that I can decrease the number of germs on it?

Yes, they can make you sick, but it is very unlikely. Some tips: The best way to keep your toothbrush free from germs is to make sure it is rinsed after each use. Let it dry thoroughly, and keep it as far away from the toilet as possible to avoid spray from flushing. Make sure to set it upright, so it is off of the counter. Enclosing the toothbrush in a toothbrush case is not a good idea, because germs thrive in the humidity. If you must keep it in a case, thoroughly dry it out with a paper towel before placing it in the case. Make sure your toothbrush does not touch anyone else's toothbrush (Even if you are married!). Most important of all, though, is get a new toothbrush regularly!

Follow these tips, and you can brush your teeth with confidence once again!
